entry.title: What is "suppression repair"
entry.summary: The overall objective of suppression repair is to repair damage caused by the fire suppression activities, and to return the affected area to pre-fire conditions as nearly as possible. Work is specifically designed to minimize surface and gully erosion, minimize sediment delivery to stream channels, restore conditions to pre-fire drainage patterns, minimize loss of soil productivity due to potential erosion in cleared areas, and minimize the introduction or spread of noxious weed infestations. The goal of water barring fire lines is to drain water off the fire line and prevent concentrated flow and ultimately soil erosion. The goal of removing berms on dozer lines is to eliminate water channeling effect. The goal of repairing roads is to return drainage elements to functioning stable condition so that they effectively route water off of the road, minimize erosion and repair damaged driving
entry.content: The overall objective of suppression repair is to repair damage caused by the fire suppression activities, and to return the affected area to pre-fire conditions as nearly as possible. Work is specifically designed to minimize surface and gully erosion, minimize sediment delivery to stream channels, restore conditions to pre-fire drainage patterns, minimize loss of soil productivity due to potential erosion in cleared areas, and minimize the introduction or spread of noxious weed infestations. The goal of water barring fire lines is to drain water off the fire line and prevent concentrated flow and ultimately soil erosion. The goal of removing berms on dozer lines is to eliminate water channeling effect. The goal of repairing roads is to return drainage elements to functioning stable condition so that they effectively route water off of the road, minimize erosion and repair damaged driving

entry.title: Sunrise and Burdette Fires Fact Sheet 09-10-17
entry.summary: Sunrise & Burdette Fires Fact Sheet 09/10/2017 Inciweb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5379/ Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/lolonationalforest/ Email: SunriseBurdetteFireInfo@gmail.com Phone: Fire information number is 406-329-3802 Location: 11 miles Southeast of Superior, MT Agency Jurisdiction: U.S. Forest Service, Lolo National Forest, Ninemile & Superior Ranger Districts Incident Command: Ken Parks, Incident Commander, SWIM IMT Current Status: Fire activity is moderate on the Sunrise Fire. Fire continues to back into Quartz Creek Drainage on the SW Corner of the fire. Burdette remains at 649 acres with minimal fire behavior and no expectation that acreage will increase. Outlook: Winds are expected to be breezy from the west. Crews will patrol and monitor the Quartz Creek drainage as weather and terrain allows. Engines will patrol the Quartz, Trout Creek and other roads around the fire to make sure roads are clear and no hot spots are near containment...
entry.content:
Sunrise and Burdette Fires Fact Sheet 09-10-17

Incident: Sunrise Fire Wildfire
Released: 28 min. ago

Related Information

  • Sunrise and Burdette Fact Sheet 09-10-17 (pdf 218 kb)

Sunrise & Burdette Fires

Fact Sheet 09/10/2017

Inciweb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5379/

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/lolonationalforest/

Email: SunriseBurdetteFireInfo@gmail.com

Phone: Fire information number is 406-329-3802

Location: 11 miles Southeast of Superior, MT

Agency Jurisdiction: U.S. Forest Service, Lolo National Forest, Ninemile & Superior Ranger Districts

Incident Command: Ken Parks, Incident Commander, SWIM IMT

Current Status: Fire activity is moderate on the Sunrise Fire. Fire continues to back into Quartz Creek Drainage on the SW Corner of the fire. Burdette remains at 649 acres with minimal fire behavior and no expectation that acreage will increase.

Outlook: Winds are expected to be breezy from the west. Crews will patrol and monitor the Quartz Creek drainage as weather and terrain allows. Engines will patrol the Quartz, Trout Creek and other roads around the fire to make sure roads are clear and no hot spots are near containment lines. Minimal fire activity is occurring on Burdette. Providing for public and firefighter safety continues to be the top priority for the incident management team. Suppression repair work on the fire is estimated to be 90% completed, and managers continue to work with the Resource Advisors to repair contingency control lines.

Crews will dispose of woody debris created during construction and improvement of contingency fire lines along roads by hauling approximately 400 dump truck loads to a disposal site and burning it in an “air curtain burner” to minimize emissions .

Key Message: Resources continue to be spread out thin on the numerous fires in the Northern Rockies Region. Managers will prioritize where the most critical needs are for equipment and personnel.

If You Fly, We Can’t! The use of unmanned aerial vehicles (drones) is prohibited near wildfires. A drone in controlled airspace can endanger aircraft, pilots and the firefighters that depend on them. Please do not use drones near wildfires!

Closures: A Stage II Evacuation notice remains in place for the Quartz Creek. Stage II is a precautionary measure that asks residents to be ready in the event that the fire changes quickly. The Forest Service area closure remains in place on the Lolo National Forest as well as Stage II Fire Restrictions.

Smoke outlook link: http://wildlandfiresmoke.net/outlooks/2017/Montana#Area5 Fire Restriction information: https://www.fs.usda.gov/lolo

Size

Percent Contained

Personnel

26,264 acres

95%

32

Air conditions were very poor, but the smoke and inversion layer allowed for higher relative humidity and cooler working conditions. Fire continues to back into Quartz Creek drainage on the SW corner of the fire. Burdette remains at 649 acres with minimal fire behavior and no expectation that acreage will increase. Friday, clearer air allowed for twenty-seven helicopter bucket drops to cool the uncontained southwest corner. Outlook:...
entry.content:
Sunrise and Burdette Fires Fact Sheet 09-09-17

Incident: Sunrise Fire Wildfire
Released: 27 min. ago

Related Information

  • Sunrise and Burdette Fires Fact Sheet 09-09-17 (pdf 92 kb)

Sunrise & Burdette Fires

Fact Sheet 09/09/2017

Inciweb: https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5379/

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/lolonationalforest/

Email: SunriseBurdetteFireInfo@gmail.com

Phone: Fire information number is 406-329-4802

Location: 11 miles Southeast of Superior, MT

Agency Jurisdiction: U.S. Forest Service, Lolo National Forest, Ninemile & Superior Ranger Districts

Incident Command: Ken Parks, Incident Commander, South West Montana IMT

Current Status: Fire activity was much less than previous days on the Sunrise Fire. Air conditions were very poor, but the smoke and inversion layer allowed for higher relative humidity and cooler working conditions. Fire continues to back into Quartz Creek drainage on the SW corner of the fire. Burdette remains at 649 acres with minimal fire behavior and no expectation that acreage will increase. Friday, clearer air allowed for twenty-seven helicopter bucket drops to cool the uncontained southwest corner.

Outlook: There is a Red Flag Warning for 9/9/17 from 1400-2100 for strong W/SW winds 9-15 mph with gusts to 25 mph. The Quartz creek drainage will continue to be patrolled and monitored by crews as weather and terrain allows. Engines will continue to patrol the Quartz, Trout Creek and other roads around the fire to make sure roads are clear and no hot spots are near containment lines. Continued ground fire in the Forty Six and Quartz Creek basins.

Providing for public and firefighter safety is the top priority for the incident management team. Suppression repair work on the fire is estimated to be 90% completed, and managers continue to work with the Resource Advisors to repair contingency control lines.

Key Message: Resources are spread thin on the numerous fires in the Northern Rockies Region. Managers will prioritize where the most critical needs are for equipment and personnel.

Closures: A Stage II Evacuation notice remains in place for the Quartz Creek. Stage II is a precautionary measure that asks residents to be ready in the event that the fire changes quickly. The Forest Service area closure remains in place on the Lolo National Forest as well as Stage II Fire Restrictions.

Incident Command: Both fires are being managed by the South West Incident Management Team, an all-hazards response team comprised of fire professionals drawn from the southwest Montana region.

Smoke outlook link: http://wildlandfiresmoke.net/outlooks/2017/Montana#Area5 Fire Restriction information: https://www.fs.usda.gov/lolo

Size

Percent Contained

Personnel

26,248 acres

95%

32

entry.title: Smoke Outlook for September 8, 2017
entry.summary: Smoke: Air Quality Alert in effect today for Missoula, Lake, and Ravalli counties. Isolated showers in the form of evaporating rain tracked through the region overnight and into the morning. Increases to moisture and instability are expected this afternoon and evening, bringing a chance for dry and wet thunderstorms. However, this potential is limited by the smoke that remains in the area.Fire: Smoky and light wind conditions have shaded fuels, limiting fire behavior. Expected changes in weather that effect fire include high pressure ridge breakdown allowing smoke to start to disperse, and potential for thunderstorms and erratic winds.Other: The high pressure ridge shifts to east starting on today, bringing conditions conducive for an increase in moisture. A cold front is anticipated to move through from the west on Saturday, strengthening westerly winds. Florence monitor is no longer
entry.content: Smoke: Air Quality Alert in effect today for Missoula, Lake, and Ravalli counties. Isolated showers in the form of evaporating rain tracked through the region overnight and into the morning. Expected changes in weather that effect fire include high pressure ridge breakdown allowing smoke to start to disperse, and potential for thunderstorms and erratic winds.Other: The high pressure ridge shifts to east starting on today, bringing conditions conducive for an increase in moisture. A cold front is anticipated to move through from the west on Saturday, strengthening westerly winds. Florence monitor is no longer

entry.title: Smoke Outlook for September 6, 2017
entry.summary: Smoke: Air Quality Alert in effect today for Missoula, Lake, and Ravalli counties. Light variable winds today including a north northwesterly component, allowing smoke to impact communities downwind from fires. High pressure remains over the region, trapping smoke in valleys overnight and mornings, heavily impacting communities closest to fires. Fire: Active fire conditions are expected to continue, with the most activity in the afternoon. Fire is anticipated to continue to be active overnight above the thermal belt. Other: As the high pressure moves across the region Thursday and Friday, winds will remain light but shift to west and then southwest, keeping dry and warm conditions. Stable weather conditions continue to create poor air quality conditions as smoke remains trapped in the region under the high pressure system. If you live within Missoula County, please refer to the Missoula City-County Health Department for detailed smoke response information (see link below). ...
entry.content:
Smoke Outlook for September 6, 2017

Incident: Burdette Fire Wildfire
Released: 29 min. ago

Smoke: Air Quality Alert in effect today for Missoula, Lake, and Ravalli counties. Light variable winds today including a north northwesterly component, allowing smoke to impact communities downwind from fires. High pressure remains over the region, trapping smoke in valleys overnight and mornings, heavily impacting communities closest to fires.

Fire: Active fire conditions are expected to continue, with the most activity in the afternoon. Fire is anticipated to continue to be active overnight above the thermal belt.

Other: As the high pressure moves across the region Thursday and Friday, winds will remain light but shift to west and then southwest, keeping dry and warm conditions. Stable weather conditions continue to create poor air quality conditions as smoke remains trapped in the region under the high pressure system. If you live within Missoula County, please refer to the Missoula City-County Health Department for detailed smoke response information (see link below).

http://wildlandfiresmoke.net/outlooks/2017/Montana#Area5

entry.title: Smoke Outlook for September 5, 2017
entry.summary: Smoke: Air Quality Alert in effect today for Missoula, Lake, and Ravalli counties. Winds, lighter today than yesterday, will continue from the east this afternoon, allowing smoke to impact communities downwind from fires today. High pressure settles into the region on Wednesday, continuing to trap smoke in valleys overnight and early morning, heavily impacting communities closest to fires. Fire: Winds at higher elevations will continue from the east today, allowing for active fire conditions to continue. Very low relative humidity and sunny skies will continue for several more days. Other: As the high pressure moves across the region Thursday and Friday, winds will remain light but shift to west and then southwest, keeping dry and hot conditions through the rest of the week. Stable weather conditions will continue to create poor air quality conditions as smoke remains trapped in the region under the high pressure system. If you live within Missoula County, please refer to the Missoula...

Winds, lighter today than yesterday, will continue from the east this afternoon, allowing smoke to impact communities downwind from fires today. High pressure settles into the region on Wednesday, continuing to trap smoke in valleys overnight and early morning, heavily impacting communities closest to fires.

Fire: Winds at higher elevations will continue from the east today, allowing for active fire conditions to continue. Very low relative humidity and sunny skies will continue for several more days.

Other: As the high pressure moves across the region Thursday and Friday, winds will remain light but shift to west and then southwest, keeping dry and hot conditions through the rest of the week. Stable weather conditions will continue to create poor air quality conditions as smoke remains trapped in the region under the high pressure system. entry.title: Smoke outlook for September 4, 2017
entry.summary: Smoke: Air Quality Alert in effect today for Missoula, Lake, and Ravalli counties. Winds turned northeast overnight and will continue today, allowing smoke from fires east of the Bitterroot Valley to create very smoky conditions today and tomorrow. Some improvement in air quality is expected this afternoon before degrading tonight in most areas. Fire: Fire activity was extremely active on many fires yesterday, generating smoke that has moved into the area overnight, persisting this morning. Critical fire weather conditions will continue along the Divide today as fires potentially burn into new areas. Other: A northeast breeze will continue today, allowing more smoke to move into the valleys, followed by a high pressure on Wednesday and Thursday which will not allow the smoke to clear out. Air quality will continue to be very poor the next several days. If you live within Missoula County, please refer to the Missoula City-County Health Department for detailed smoke response information...

entry.title: Stakeholder Meeting Tuesday September 5, 2017
entry.summary: A stakeholder meeting is scheduled for Tuesday September 5, 2017 at 10:00am. The location of the meeting will be at the Sunrise Fire Incident Command Post in Tarkio.
entry.content: A stakeholder meeting is scheduled for Tuesday September 5, 2017 at 10:00am. The location of the meeting will be at the Sunrise Fire Incident Command Post in Tarkio.

entry.title: Stage II Evacuations back in place for Quartz Creek Residents
entry.summary: Stage II Evacuations were set in place by the Mineral County Sherriff this evening for the Quartz Creek residents. Stage II is a pre-evacuation warning and residents should be prepared to evacuate if fire conditions worsen. This is not an immediate evacuation. The Sunrise Fire became more active yesterday September 3, 2017 and continued movement in the Quartz Creek drainage. Fire managers are concerned with the upcoming weather and dry fuel conditions in the area.
entry.content: Stage II Evacuations were set in place by the Mineral County Sherriff this evening for the Quartz Creek residents. Stage II is a pre-evacuation warning and residents should be prepared to evacuate if fire conditions worsen. This is not an immediate evacuation. The Sunrise Fire became more active yesterday September 3, 2017 and continued movement in the Quartz Creek drainage. Fire managers are concerned with the upcoming weather and dry fuel conditions in the area.

entry.title: Smoke Outlook for Sunday September 3, 2017
entry.summary: Smoke: Air Quality Alert in effect today for Missoula, Lake, and Ravalli counties. Smoke will persist this morning in the Bitterroot Valley, lifting some this afternoon. Smoke will return in areas closest to active fires this afternoon as fire activity increases; smoke will become much more widespread overnight. Fire: Extremely hot and dry conditions will persist for one more day across the Northern Rockies. These dry conditions will combine with breezy westerly winds and an unstable atmosphere this afternoon and evening to create critical fire weather conditions across western Montana. Other: Winds will switch by tomorrow from the west to the east, creating problematic fire weather conditions tonight into Monday. High pressure will return by Wednesday, bring back hot and dry conditions, conducive to stagnant air and smoky skies. If you live within Missoula County, please refer to the Missoula City-County Health Department for detailed smoke response information (see link below). ...
entry.content:

entry.title: Smoke Outlook for September 2 & 3 , 2017
entry.summary: Smoke: Somewhat better air quality will continue across the area today with daytime west winds, becoming calmer overnight, allowing smoke to settle back down into valleys by early morning. Increased fire activity due to higher winds, especially on Sunday, will produce more smoke overall. Fire: Dry and breezy conditions today will lead to critical fire weather conditions in some areas today, higher winds on Sunday will lead to more widespread critical fire weather conditions. Fire activity will be influence by these winds, which will strongest at higher elevations. Other: Winds will increase, strongest at higher elevations, today and tomorrow with even drier air moving into the region tonight. The next change in the weather is Monday and Tuesday when cooler weather and east winds are possible. If you live within Missoula County, please refer to the Missoula City-County Health Department for detailed smoke response information (see link below). ...
entry.content:
Smoke Outlook for September 2 & 3 , 2017

Incident: Sunrise Fire Wildfire
Released: 4 hrs. ago

Smoke: Somewhat better air quality will continue across the area today with daytime west winds, becoming calmer overnight, allowing smoke to settle back down into valleys by early morning. Increased fire activity due to higher winds, especially on Sunday, will produce more smoke overall.

Fire: Dry and breezy conditions today will lead to critical fire weather conditions in some areas today, higher winds on Sunday will lead to more widespread critical fire weather conditions. Fire activity will be influence by these winds, which will strongest at higher elevations.

Other: Winds will increase, strongest at higher elevations, today and tomorrow with even drier air moving into the region tonight. The next change in the weather is Monday and Tuesday when cooler weather and east winds are possible. If you live within Missoula County, please refer to the Missoula City-County Health Department for detailed smoke response information (see link below).

http://wildlandfiresmoke.net/outlooks/2017/Montana#N

If you live within Missoula County, please refer to the Missoula City-County Health Department for detailed smoke response information (see link below). ...
entry.content:
Smoke Outlook for September 2, 2017

Incident: Burdette Fire Wildfire
Released: 4 hrs. ago

Smoke: Somewhat better air quality will continue across the area today with daytime west winds, becoming calmer overnight, allowing smoke to settle back down into valleys by early morning. Increased fire activity due to higher winds, especially on Sunday, will produce more smoke overall.

Fire: Dry and breezy conditions today will lead to critical fire weather conditions in some areas today, higher winds on Sunday will lead to more widespread critical fire weather conditions. Fire activity will be influence by these winds, which will strongest at higher elevations.

Other: Winds will increase, strongest at higher elevations, today and tomorrow with even drier air moving into the region tonight. The next change in the weather is Monday and Tuesday when cooler weather and east winds are possible. If you live within Missoula County, please refer to the Missoula City-County Health Department for detailed smoke response information (see link below).

http://wildlandfiresmoke.net/outlooks/2017/Montana#N

Frenchtown and Missoula’s air quality will be best represented by...
entry.content:
Smoke Outlook for September 1 2017

Incident: Sunrise Fire Wildfire
Released: 1 day ago

Smoke: Overall Friday is best represented by “Good” to “Moderate” for air quality. Smoke is expected to filter back into valley locations overnight. Air quality for the weekend is expected to degrade.

Fire: The Sunrise fire is located 11 miles SE of Superior, MT adjacent to I-90. Southwest portion of the fire continues to back and flank. Minimal fire growth has been observed and an increase in acreage is not expected on the Sunrise fire.

Other: Slightly cooler temperatures Friday accompanied by breezy west winds on the ridgetops. A strong ridge of high pressure will re-establish itself across the Western United States through the upcoming weekend brining record high temperatures and continued dry conditions. Fires with active perimeters should expect an increase in fire behavior. Air quality has improved across the forecast area and is expected to remain in the “Good” range for Superior and Alberton. Frenchtown and Missoula’s air quality will be best represented by “Moderate”, and Missoula may experience “USG” overnight. If you live within Missoula County, please refer to the Missoula CityCounty Health Department for detailed smoke health information (see link below).

Additional Links
DEQ Today's Air
Missoula County Air Quality Updates

Health effects categories and visibility
ArcGIS Wildfire Maps

Inciweb Sunrise http://wildlandfiresmoke.net/outlooks/2017/Montana#Area2

Smoke Outlook for September 1 2017

Incident: Burdette Fire Wildfire
Released: 1 day ago

Smoke: Overall Friday is best represented by “Good” to “Moderate” for air quality. Smoke is expected to filter back into valley locations overnight. Air quality for the weekend is expected to degrade.

Fire: The Sunrise fire is located 11 miles SE of Superior, MT adjacent to I-90. Southwest portion of the fire continues to back and flank. Minimal fire growth has been observed and an increase in acreage is not expected on the Sunrise fire.

Other: Slightly cooler temperatures Friday accompanied by breezy west winds on the ridgetops. A strong ridge of high pressure will re-establish itself across the Western United States through the upcoming weekend brining record high temperatures and continued dry conditions. Fires with active perimeters should expect an increase in fire behavior. Air quality has improved across the forecast area and is expected to remain in the “Good” range for Superior and Alberton. Frenchtown and Missoula’s air quality will be best represented by “Moderate”, and Missoula may experience “USG” overnight. If you live within Missoula County, please refer to the Missoula CityCounty Health Department for detailed smoke health information (see link below).
